description: Erection of an additional floor at fourth floor level to provide 2 flats comprising 2x3 bed residential units, with associated stairwell and lift enclosure and cycle and refuse store (additional information and revised cycle storage arrangements).
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall be commenced within 3 years from the date of this decision.Reason: In order to comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act, 1990.  (As amended).

Prior to the commencement of development, samples and manufacturers specifications of the facing materials to be utilised in the development hereby permitted shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall then be built in accordance with the approved details.Reason: These details are required prior to the commencement of development as the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the commencement of the development hereby approved, and notwithstanding the details shown on the approved plans stated in Condition 2 of this permission, the following details shall have been submitted in writing (on plans at a scale of no less than 1:10) and approved by the Local Planning Authority.Window reveals, door reveals, overhangs, rainwater goods, balustradesThe development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details.Reason: These details are required prior to the commencement of development  as the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset to ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012).

No development shall take place (including any works of demolition) until a construction management plan or construction method statement has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:i) How the proposed development will be built;ii) Hours of working (which shall be limited to 08.00 to 18.00 Mondays to Fridays and between 08.00 to 13.00 on Saturdays and not at all on Bank Holidays and Sundays);iii) The procedure for loading/unloading materials;iv) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;v) The protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;vi) The protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; vii) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site and whether a banksman will be provided;viii) Temporary site access;ix) Signing system for works traffic;x) Whether site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads;xi) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site;xii) The storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;xiii) The potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;xiv) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;xv) The location of all ancillary site buildings;xvi) The means of enclosure of the site, its erection and maintenance;xvii) Wheel washing equipment;xviii) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors;xix) Meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used); andxx) The method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phasesDeliveries/collections to and from the site shall use a route that is agreed with the highway authority and the agreed route shall be signed accordingly.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and they are needed to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted, hard and soft landscaping and boundary treatment details of the rooftop terrace, including their manufacturer's specification, height, colour and texture shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved details shall be implemented prior to the occupation of the development and retained as such for the life of the development. Reason: In the interest of visual and neighbouring amenity in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted, the following details shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved details shall be implemented prior to the occupation of the development and retained as such for the life of the development. (a)  waste and recycling storage facilities (materials, design and dimensions)(b)  cycle storage facilities (materials, design and dimensions)Reason: To provide adequate refuse and recycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 105L per person per day have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The hours of working during the development phase shall be restricted to the following:Monday - Friday: 8am - 6pmSaturday: 8am - 1pmNo working on Sundays or Bank Holidays.Reason: To safeguard the amenity of the occupants of surrounding premises during the demolition/construction phase in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No fans, louvres, ducts or other external plant other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved shall be installed without the prior written approval of the Local Planning Authority. Reason: To safeguard the amenities of the occupiers of the neighbouring properties and the visual amenities of the area in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

With the exception of the approved rooftop amenity area, as shown on '19087-GAA-ZZ-RF-DR-T-2007, Proposed Roof Level', the flat roof areas of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Condition 3 of planning permission ref: 21/04089/FUL (Allowed at Appeal ref: APP/Z5630/W/22/3300875) dated 21.12.2022 is as follows:'Prior to the commencement of the development hereby approved, details of mitigation measures to prevent harm to features for which Epsom and Ashtead Commons Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) has been notified shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority for approval in writing, including: -details of a Construction Environmental Management Plan detailing the construction phase sustainable drainage system to ensure surface water run-off does not reach the SSSI during works on site; - details of the operational phase sustainable drainage system (pond) to direct run-off away from the SSSI and a timetable for its implementation;- details of the fixed position of the area for storage of manure and stable waste products away from the SSSI boundary to minimise the risk of nutrient enrichment within the SSSI; and a timescale and method statement for the removal of the earth mounds/soil bund detailed in section 4.2.6 of the Preliminary Ecological Appraisal (David Archer Associates, December 2021).The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved mitigation measures and shall thereafter be maintained in perpetuity.'Natural England provided a consultation response on 27 October 2023 raising no objection to the application. Officers are therefore satisfied that the details submitted pursuant to Condition 3 are considered to be acceptable.

Officer report:This application seeks to modify the wording of a Planning Obligation (Deed) accompanying planning permission 20/00945/FUL. The modification proposes that the Obligation be amended to allow for the staggered payment of the carbon offset contribution in two payments. There is no variation in the overall payment sum and no other changes to the deed.The first instalment (50%) would be paid on or before the Commencement of Development and the development is not toCommence until the said instalment has been paid. The second and final instalment (remaining 50%) would be paid within 12 months of the Commencement of Development. Officers are satisfied that the staggering of the payments as suggested by the applicant would still achieve the aims of the legal agreement, i.e. to ensure payment is received early in the development phase.

Condition 4 of planning permission ref: 21/04089/FUL (Allowed at Appeal ref: APP/Z5630/W/22/3300875) dated 21.12.2022 is as follows:'Prior to the commencement of the development hereby approved (including any works of demolition), a construction management plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The statement shall provide for:i) the route to and away from site for machinery and vehicles with materials;ii) the storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;iii) the potential for impacts from dust and emissions during the demolition and/or construction phase upon local air quality and surrounding residents;iv) measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;v) wheel washing equipment;vi) meeting the requirements of the Low Emission Zone for Non-Road Mobile Machinery (where relevant plant or vehicles are being used); andvii) the method of recycling and disposing of waste resulting from the demolition and/or construction phases.The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period.'The Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer has reviewed the submitted information and confirms that they raise no objection. The details submitted pursuant to Condition 4 are considered to be acceptable.

Condition 5 of planning permission ref: 21/04089/FUL (Allowed at Appeal ref: APP/Z5630/W/22/3300875) dated 21.12.2022 is as follows:' Prior to the commencement of the development hereby approved, a detailed landscaping and landscape management scheme shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The submitted information shall include:- details of trees to be planted, species, size and density. Any such details to include species such as hazel and hawthorn along the boundary of the SSSI;- the composition and extent of area to be planted as a wildflower meadow;- the size of the surface water pond and any associated bund, along with soft landscaping measures in relation to either or both.- details of the mix of species to be included within any hedgerows shown on the plans (forming the boundaries of the garden and along the Right of Way.- a timetable for implementation and a long-term management plan in respect of the same, for a period of least five years following the development.The development shall be implemented in accordance with the approved scheme.'The Council's Tree & Landscape Officer reviewed application ref: 23/01418/CLC which also sought to discharge this condition and raised no objection. Noting that the relevant landscape and planting information remains unchanged as part of the current application, Officers are satisfied that the details submitted to discharge Condition 5 are acceptable.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling on the corner of Highfield Road and Woodside Close.ProposalDemolition of side lean-to and rear extension, and erection of single storey rear extension, two storey side extension, and rear dormer roof extension with Juliet balcony and 3nos. front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion.ConsultationFour neighbouring properties have been notified and 1 representation has been received neither supporting or objecting to the development. Issues that have been raised are;- Loss of privacy due to the Juliet balcony; and- Builders' vehicles creating difficulties for parking and heavy loads damaging roads and pathways.Regarding highway issues, the applicant would be reminded of their responsibilities to highway safety and damage repair should permission be granted. The issue of privacy will be addressed under neighbouring amenity.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire safety. DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Officers note that the proposed development would not be compliant with Policy Guidance 36 of the Residential Design SPD. It is also noted that similar corner properties along Highfield Road have been extended in this way. However, the proposed development would result in a disproportionate and bulky extension and roof form which does not reflect the existing roof pitch which would appear appears "top-heavy" and monolithic.  The proposed rear dormer also does not reflect the SPG guidance and the use of render instead of hanging roof tile would exacerbate its prominence within the street scene when viewed to the rear. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be unacceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be an adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: With regards to the proposed rear extension, officers note that No. 1 Highfield Road does not benefit from a rear extension, However it is noted that there is currently a garden shed on the patio. The proposed rear extension would measure approximately 4.5m in depth and 3m in height with a flat roof and would be compliant with BRE guidance in relation to the 45 degree rule. With regards to the proposed Juliet balcony, it is not considered that the proposed opening would give rise to further overlooking as the outlook would remain the same as that of the first floor windows. Overall, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.Building RegulationsYour attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation.  These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

Condition 6 of planning permission ref: 21/04089/FUL (Allowed at Appeal ref: APP/Z5630/W/22/3300875) dated 21.12.2022 is as follows:'Prior to the commencement of the development hereby approved, details of a scheme to enhance the nature conservation interest of the site and an associated program for implementation and management of the same shall be submitted to and agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved scheme shall be implemented in accordance with the approved programme.'The submission includes an Ecological Enhancement Strategy dated April 2023, prepared by David Archer Associates and a Method Statement - Reptiles. The Strategy details native planting which includes shrubs, trees and hedgerows and other enhancements such as a wildlife pond and reedbed. Additionally, 3 Schwegler and/or 2F bat boxes would be installed along with 2 hedgehog houses. The Strategy includes maintenance details.The details submitted pursuant to Condition 6 are considered to be acceptable.

Condition 10 of planning permission ref: 21/04089/FUL (Allowed at Appeal ref: APP/Z5630/W/22/3300875) dated 21.12.2022 is as follows:'Notwithstanding the approved drawings and prior to any works above damp proof course level, details shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority indicating the positions, design, materials and type of all boundary treatment, fences and means of enclosures to be erected. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved details prior to the occupation of the dwellings.'The details of boundary treatment appear to be shown on 997-L-01, Rev B and 997-L-02. Based on these drawings boundary treatment would comprise hedgerows and shrub mixes. Within the context of Condition 16 which states:  'Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and re-enacting that Order with or without modification), no additions or enlargements to the dwellinghouse or outbuildings on the site other than those expressly authorised by this permission, or means of enclosure or hardstanding shall be constructed.'it is considered that the details of hedgerow and shrub mixes to be used as means of enclosure would be acceptable. Were any other means of enclosure to be erected at a later date these would require planning permission.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling6 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are: - The impact of the development on character and appearance. - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development on fire safety. This planning application seeks to obtain planning permission for partial demolition of the existing rear extension, erection of a two-storey side, part two-storey/part single-storey rear and single-storey front porch extension.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application partly proposes the construction of a two-storey side extension. Officers note that the proposed two-storey side extension would only be set down from the ridge line of the existing dwelling house by approximately 300mm. Whilst this aspect would not strictly meet the requirements of the Residential Design SPD 2013, which requires two-storey side extensions to be set down from the ridge by at least 500mm to ensure a less prominent appearance in the streetscene, this would not warrant refusal alone as overall it would be a subordinate and proportionate addition.Additionally, this extension would not exceed 50% of the width of the original house, it would be set back sufficiently from the front elevation by approximately 1m and would be set in from the boundary by approximately 6.5m (towards the rear) - 3.4m (towards the front). This element is therefore considered to have an acceptable impact in terms of character and appearance.The application also proposes the construction of a part two-storey rear extension. Officers acknowledge that this element of the proposal would be of a significant scale and would be visible in the streetscene, as it sited to the rear of the dwelling. However, it would be located on a spacious plot and would blend in well with the existing dwelling, therefore, officers consider that it would not have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area. The applicant proposes the construction of a single-storey rear extension with a flat roof. Whilst this extension would exceed the recommended depth for single-storey rear extensions, it would appear proportionate to the the host dwelling by maintaining a flat roof height of approximately 2.9m, in line with Policy Guidance 33, of the Residential Design SPD.In regards to the proposed front porch, officers consider it would not significantly affect the character and appearance of the original dwelling or the street generally. Although it would not respect the features of the adjoining property No.90 Lawrence Avenue, the proposal would respect the pitched roof form of the existing roof and would appear subordinate. Therefore, on balance, officers consider that the proposal would appear proportionate to the original dwellinghouse and therefore would not have an unacceptable impact on its character and appearance. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: Officers have assessed the impact on daylighting and sunlighting of the proposed rear extension, using the BRE, 45 & 25 Degree Rule and the Residential Design SPD to ensure minimum impact on neighbouring amenities.The proposed two-storey rear/side extension sits at a reasonable distance from neighbouring properties No.90 Lawrence Avenue and No. 35 Kneller Road. In terms of privacy, Policy Guidance 16, of the Residential Design SPD states that a separation distance of 7.5m should be maintained between new habitable room windows and the boundary to neighbouring properties or 15m between new habitable room windows and the flank wall of a neighbouring property. The separating distance between the shared boundary with No.35 Kneller Road and the new habitable room on the first floor would be approximately 7.8m complying with the guidance. The proposed single-storey rear extension, on the shared boundary with no. 90 Lawrence Avenue, would have a depth of approximately 4.5m and a flat roof height of approximately 2.9m, compared to the existing rear extension with a depth of approximately 5m with a pitched stepped height ranging from approximately 3.5m to 2.5m and an eaves height of approximately 2.4-2m. A rear extension with this depth would usually be considered unacceptable and the eaves height would increase by approximately 900-500mm. However, officers have assessed the effect of the extension on elevation and it is considered that there would be no significant loss of light due to the proposed single-storey rear extension. Additionally, while the eaves height would be higher than existing the overall height of extension would be lower and approximately 0.5m reduced in depth.  On balance, the proposed rear extension would not appear overbearing compared to the existing single-storey rear extension to be demolished.Overall, given the siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2023), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

PLEASE READ CAREFULLY: On the 1st May 2024 the Council adopted a new Householder Local List. Please ensure that your application submission includes all the necessary documentation as required by the new local list. Then please complete and submit a Householder Checklist - Section 3 to confirm that you have provided all mandatory documents  The new Householder Local List and checklists can be obtained via the council's website: https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applicationsThe LPA will not conduct any validation checks until the correct Checklist has been submitted. Upon receipt of a completed Checklist, the application will be assigned to a validation officer to review. Please do not simply state N/A anywhere in the checklist without a written justification. If you need to make any changes to your application please try to do this via the Planning Portal website where possible. If that is not possible please send amended documents via the email address quoted in this letter.

The Local List requires a completed Biodiversity Checklist for all applications. Please download and complete a copy of the Biodiversity Checklist from: https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applications

Validation Checklist Update - Please ensure you have provided all documents required to support your application in line with the Local List and update the Checklist document with any changes you have made to your application.  Please give clear reasons if not providing mandatory documents.

I acknowledge receipt of your payment for £578, the fee required for this application is £1156, therefore please forward the outstanding balance of £578 as soon as possible.Note: Payment can be made online via the Kingston council website, or via our Contact Centre on 020 8547 5002.
Scale Bar Issue - the scale bar on the Balcony Section plan 317_GA_260_pp is incorrect at scale 1:20. Please check and amend the scale bar.

There is 'Yes' in Part-1 Section 2.9 (Hedgerows supporting mainly native species) of buiodiversity checklist, therefore please complete Part-3 with supporting statement.Please revise 'Biodiversity Checklist.' Please check the new local list in our website before filling the householder validation checklist.The new local list and validation checklists can be obtained via the council's website- https://www.kingston.gov.uk/downloads/download/261/validation-requirements-for-planning-applications.

The submitted existing and proposed block plan does not show complete outline of the site. Please provide existing and proposed block plan/site plan drawn at an identified standard metric scale (such as 1:200 or 1:500) showing the proposed works in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site. The site plan should show all public rights of way crossing or adjoining the site and should also show access arrangements, all trees and hedges within the application site and on the boundary, including trees and hedges on neighbouring land.  The plan should be annotated with key measurements, including distances to boundaries. The plan(s) must be given a unique drawing number and be clearly labelled as Existing or Proposed Site Plan. The Site Plan must show the direction of North.
Please submit '45 Degree Plan/Statement'.
